text: - [Narrator] This invention could
help save more disaster victims.
2017 was a bad year for the U.S.
It spent an estimated $306 billion dollars

on fixing the damage
from natural disasters.
One of the most expensive years on record.

But those toppled homes and
flooded streets aren't just

expensive to clean up, they
block the way for rescue crews
making it even harder to help disaster
victims in need of medical aid.

Rescue crews can drop
supplies from the air
but even those can have rough landings,

breaking fragile medical
equipment on impact.

That's where something
like this could help.

It's called the Dazzle
Box, and it won first place

at this year's 3M Disruptive
Design Challenge.

The challenge? Test college
engineering students

to build a container that
could successfully deliver
needed medical supplies if air dropped
into the midst of a natural disaster.

The guidelines? The
device must be resilient,

easy to transport from
one point to another,
able to be reused after the drop,
and water resistant.

- So we were supposed
to design a container
that would have a parachute but be able
to survive if that parachute failed.
First and foremost it had to survive
a 150 foot drop from the crane.

- [Narrator] Not many
projects survived the drop.

Ultimately it was the
iconic shape that gave
this team a leg up on the competition.

- So we went through a
lot of different shapes.

The shape we settled on
for the final container
is called a truncated octahedron.

We chose that one
specifically because it's

still sort of round, it
has that sort of profile
but it also is really easy to transport

because it can stack perfectly
with itself in space.

So it makes it very efficient
to transport as well.

- [Narrator] The device was
made of individual polycarbonate

panels that the team taped
together and lined with foam.

This not only made the device
more resistant on impact
but it also made it extremely versatile.

- One of the major design
decisions that we made

and the tape helped this
decision also is that all

the polycarbonate panels
and all the pieces

are completely modular
so you can just cut one

out if it's broken and
replace it with a new one.
Put down new tape and then the container
would be ready to drop again after that.

We also had a lot of foam that
helped to absorb the impact

and that was used, you know
you could make beddings,

you could make cushions,
pillows, really anything

that you need to use it
for, it could be cut up
and made into sponges if you needed it.

- [Narrator] Last but not
least was the colorful design.

- Yeah so that was inspired
by this thing called

Dazzle Camouflage, there
was a marine artist named

Norman Wilkinson who developed
it actually for the Royal,

the British Royal Navy to be
put on the side of their ships

so that it would be harder
for enemy ships to see

the ship's heading because
the sort of sharp geometric

pattern broke up where
that ship was heading.

And it sort of also has the
secondary effect of making

anything stand out in
any natural environment.

It's a very like unnatural
pattern so we wanted to use

that aspect just so our
container, if it fell into

the jungle where there may
be like heavy underbrush

or different things,
it would really, really

stand out against that
natural environment.
- [Narrator] They also added LED emergency
lights on each face of the container
so it could be equally visible at night.

In total, the team spent about
$600 building the device.
But it paid off in the end.

- So each member of our team
is gonna get a $1500 cash

prize which is awesome and
then I think we also just

get some bragging rights
'cause we're the inaugural

winners of the 3M Disruptive
Design Competition.

- [Narrator] And while
the team has no plans
to pursue the project beyond this point.

- All of us did the challenge
as an extra-curricular
activity but I think we would be open
to any opportunities that pop up.
(soft gentle music)
